page.title: 01Freefolk Wood and areas near
page.content: This area is undulating ground of lightchalk soil with occasional pockets of clay. it includes three sizeable woods. Brickiln (forestry) Laverstoke (Amenity) and Freefolk which is an ancient deciduous woodland with very wide rrides. Dating from Saxon times it has tumili on the north east and outhern sides which also has remins of the original parish boundary ditch. it contains many specimens of wild flowers and butterflies, farmland, arable, growing wheat barley, grass for sed, silage, and oil seed rape. One flock of sheep and a small number of bullocks are grazed. Woodland and hedge row trees are oak, beech, ash, sycamore, cherry, hazel, fieldmaple, birch and a few larch. Elms are dead but many young trees rising from suckers, buildings amixture of old brick and flint and
